3.2.1.title: Design and Function
3.2.1.content:
**How It Works:**
Annular preventers use a donut-shaped rubber element that, when squeezed by hydraulic pressure, closes around any shape or size of pipe in the bore.

**Element:**
- Reinforced rubber compound
- Deforms to seal around pipe, kelly, casing, or open hole
- Different element types for different applications

**Operating Principle:**
1. Hydraulic pressure applied to close side
2. Piston pushes down on element
3. Element is squeezed inward
4. Element seals around pipe or closes on open hole
5. Wellbore pressure helps maintain seal

3.2.2.title: Capabilities
3.2.2.content:
**Sealing Around:**
- Drillpipe (various sizes)
- Tool joints
- Kelly (if used)
- Casing
- Wireline
- Open hole (complete closure)

**Stripping:**
- Can strip pipe through with element partially closed
- Reduces operating pressure for stripping
- Wear on element - monitor condition

**Limitations:**
- Cannot shear pipe
- Element wears with use
- Temperature and chemical exposure degrade element
- Limited cycles before replacement needed

3.2.3.title: Operating Pressure
3.2.3.content:
**Closing Pressure:**
- Higher pressure = tighter seal
- Pressure needed depends on wellbore pressure and pipe size
- Manufacturer provides closing pressure charts

**Typical:**
- Full close (no pipe): 1500 psi operating
- Around drillpipe: 1200-1500 psi
- Stripping: 600-1000 psi (reduced)

**Regulating:**
- Use regulator on control system
- Avoid over-pressuring (damages element)
- Adjust for operation (sealing vs stripping)

**Wellbore Assist:**
Wellbore pressure helps keep element closed. Higher well pressure requires less closing pressure.

3.2.4.title: Testing
3.2.4.content:
**Pressure Test:**
- Test to working pressure on pipe
- Test to lower pressure on open hole (element-only seal)
- Per API RP 53 or applicable standard

**Function Test:**
- Verify opens and closes fully
- Check closing time
- Observe for leaks
- Typically at initial installation and periodically

**Element Inspection:**
- Visual inspection when practical
- Check for cuts, tears, swelling
- Replace if damaged or excessively worn

**Documentation:**
- Record all tests
- Note any anomalies
- Track element usage (cycles, stripping distance)

3.2.5.title: Maintenance
3.2.5.content:
**Element Life:**
- Depends on usage, temperature, fluid exposure
- Stripping wears element significantly
- Track cycles and operating conditions

**Replacement:**
- Replace per manufacturer recommendation
- Replace if damaged
- Replace after significant stripping operations
- Have spare elements on location

**Seals:**
- Piston seals require periodic replacement
- Check for leaks during function tests
- Follow manufacturer service intervals
